title: staying out sun isnt always
story: NewsWhy staying out of the sun isn't always better for you - common heatwave myths bustedStop yourself from falling for one of these heatwave myths and make yourself as comfortable as can be during the warm weather&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByCourtney Pochin11:51, 24 JUL 2018NewsSometimes it's not always best to stay indoors on a hot day (Image: Getty)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe sun is shining and temperatures are rising once again. This heatwave doesn't seem to be letting up any time soon, but what's the best way to deal with it? You've probably searched for all sorts of tips and tricks on coping with the warm weather, but have they been working for you? It's easy to fall for some of the most common heatwave myths as they often make a lot of sense.  To save you from falling for them, here's a look at some of the most common ones as shared by Public Health Matters , and the things you should try instead.   Opening windows will keep you cool inside In times of great heat, you might think the obvious solution is to throw open all the windows and create a breeze. However, if it's hotter outside than it is inside, you're probably just letting all the hot air into your home. The trick is to open the windows when the air outside feels cooler than the air inside your home, for example at night, but be aware of security concerns. To prevent heat entering your home through the windows, try covering those that are directly exposed to direct sunlight - you could do this with external shutters or shades.  If not, internal blinds or curtains are less effective but are cheaper and easier to install. You can also reduce heat accumulating indoors by turning off all non-essential electrical equipment. It's not always better to stay out of the sun Often during periods of high temperatures, we are told to stay indoors and out of the sun. But that's not always the best idea. Homes and buildings with air conditioning are likely to prove safer for some, but that doesn't mean other homes won't be overheating.  Top floor flats and single aspect flats are most at risk of this and residents may find it is cooler to go to a park where there is breeze and some shade, than stay at home. If you don't fancy going to the park, there are many air conditioned public buildings you can visit, such as museums or libraries. The best advice is to simply consider your own environment. There are various things you can do to keep your home as cool as possible and give yourself some respite from the heat. Sunburn is the biggest health worry in the sun Sunburn is definitely something we need to protect ourself from, but the heat itself poses a significant health risk.  People can become dehydrated very quickly and can develop other health related illnesses. The greatest health risks in hot weather are to those with underlying health problems (such as heart and lung conditions), older people and young children. This is because heat puts significant additional strains on their bodies and can cause major health problems, and can even kill. Only older people die in hot weather  Not true. Fit and healthy people can also succumb to heat illness in very high temperatures or when doing very strenuous activity, whether novices at the London marathon or professional cyclists in the Tour de France. There may also be hidden dangers you hadn't considered, for example risks of injury or drowning when swimming in rivers and reservoirs. White cotton is the best fabric to wear during a heatwave Natural fabrics such as linen and cotton are great during the heat as they absorb sweat and allow your skin to breathe. However it's not completely true you should always opt for white or light coloured clothing.  White is said to be a good choice if you're spending lots of time in direct sunlight as it will help reflect the heat, but if you're spending time in the shade black is the more effective colour to wear. This is because it radiates out heat into the environment, cooling you down. When you're hot drinking lots of cold water is a good idea It is a great idea to keep yourself hydrated, drinking lots of water. But if you down lots of icy water in a short period of time, you could make yourself ill.  Dr Sarah Jarvis, GP and clinical director of Patient.info, explained why to the Sun .   She said: If you drink something very cold, very quickly, the cold on the roof of your mouth stimulates the nerves around there. That in turn leads to rapid contraction, then expanding of the tiny blood vessels in your sinuses. The brain interrupts the messages from these nerves as coming from your forehead, because the same nerve supplies your forehead. She said this normally results in a sudden pain and it can make you feel lightheaded. Drinking hot drinks will help with the heat This one is an awkward one.  Drinking hot drinks will raise your body temperature making you sweat. Sweating cools you down because as the moisture evaporates it takes away some of the heat from your body. But sweating also means that you are losing liquid from your body, so you need to drink on more to stay hydrated. You should point your fan at yourself to cool down New Zealand-based eco design adviser, Nelson Lebo recommends turning the fan to face out the open window, instead of pointing it at yourself. The method works as the fan blows the warm air from your home outwards and pulls cooler air in.

title: sweet shop owner fed up
story: NewsSweet shop owner fed up with police 'inaction' posts photos of 'shoplifters' in window with word 'THIEF'John Keppie, manager at Sweet Thoughts in Bournemouth, Dorset, said he decided to take action after police failed to investigate the shoplifting&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByTom DavidsonOnline Reporter15:00, 24 JUL 2018Updated15:05, 24 JUL 2018NewsJohn Keppie is sick of what he calls police inaction tackling shoplifters at his business (Image: BNPS)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A shop manager has put up posters of suspected shoplifters in his window after becoming fed up with a lack of action to the petty crime by the police .   Images taken from CCTV cameras at the sweet shop have been blown up to A4 size and stuck in the window.  The word 'THIEF' is printed above each image in large capital letters and the posters are clearly visible to passers-by. John Keppie, manager at Sweet Thoughts in Bournemouth, Dorset, said he decided to take action after police failed to investigate the shoplifting, despite being offered CCTV images. Several members of the public have also given the names of the alleged offenders to staff.  But Mr Keppie said that since the three posters appeared he has received a telephone call from the police telling him he isn't allowed to have them up. He could be in breach of the Data Protection Act (2018) and liable to a fine. His actions come after other shop owners across the country claim police have given up investigating shoplifting incidents due to a lack of manpower. In some cases there has been compelling CCTV evidence. Mr Keppie said: It was me who put the pictures in the window because I've had enough of it now. I've spoken to the police and I know I'm not meant to have them up but until someone actually comes down and makes me take them down then they will be staying up. The thee girls came in and stole three drinks from the fridge. I gave chase and they actually turned round and spat at me. I told the police but they said they have more important things that they have to deal with.  One officer came down here and spent literally seven seconds in the shop. Their response did not leave me best pleased. I know I'm not meant to have the pictures up but if they're big enough to steal and spit in my face then they're big enough to deal with it. One of the things I've done now is send the pictures to every school in Bournemouth and Poole asking if the girls attended there. I didn't need a name, just a yes or no. One got back to me and I passed that onto the police but as yet I'm still waiting to hear if anything has happened. Shoplifting is a fairly common occurrence and you can spot the ones who do it from the minute they walk in the shop. Kevin Strudwick, the crime manager for Bournemouth Business Reducing Crime Partnership, a co-operative of local business, police and council, said the 'wanted' posters risked turning the resort into the 'Wild West'. Mr Strudwick said: Unfortunately with Data Protection laws you have to be very careful with what you do. Putting 'wanted' posters on the wall is returning to the old days of the Wild West. The CPS would not look upon it as the right thing to do and the police would also take a dim view. I sympathise with any shop which has sustained losses as they are devastating but you have to follow the laws, simple as that. It would be a different story if the shoplifter was convicted and you showed the poster to staff at the back of the store but never on public display. You also could have the situation where someone's parents or grandparents could see the poster who had no idea about what had happened, which would a great shock for them.

title: uks worst motorway service stations
story: NewsUK's worst motorway service stations - and the best as voted by customersThurrock Services, on the M25, was described by disgruntled drivers as ­“gloriously ugly” and “a building site” with reviews claiming the station's toilets were "disgusting"&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByRuki SayidConsumer Editor00:00, 24 JUL 2018Updated00:04, 24 JUL 2018NewsThurrock Services, on the M25, was described by disgruntled drivers as “gloriously ugly” and “a building site” (Image: Internet Unknown)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA motorway service station has been branded Britain’s worst after it left drivers without even the chance of a coffee during a revamp. Thurrock Services, on the M25, was described by disgruntled drivers as &shy“gloriously ugly” and “a building site”. Reviews claimed the service station’s toilets were “disgusting” and advised: “Avoid if you have other options.” But while the Essex pit-stop was bottom on just 68% in the poll by watchdog Transport Focus, the top six were all found in the Midlands or the North.  Top-rated Norton Canes, on the M6 in Staffordshire, was awarded a perfect 100 – impressing users with its clean toilets, friendly staff and food and drink options. However drivers must pay &pound5.90 during the week to access the toll road it is on.  Also on the M6, Stafford Southbound won praise for a facelift on its much-hated toilets, while Wetherby on the A1M impressed with revamped seating, a drive-through Costa and new outlets. Heston East on the M4 also stepped up with revamped loos and a Greggs to score 88, up from 62 last year.  But while nine out of 10 users were happy with facilities and staff, a third said food and drink were poor value. And two-thirds moaned at rip-off fuel prices. Checks by the Mirror found service station petrol as much as 19p a litre up on the national average, at 147.9p.  Lucky motorists at Tiverton on the M5 pay a 3p premium at 131.9p a litre. The poll of 9,600 visitors to 111 motorway service stations found three quarters stopped for the toilets, while only half bought food and drink.

title: uk weather met office issues
story: NewsMet Office issues weather warning of thunder, lightning, giant hailstones and strong winds for millionsA severe weather warning for thunderstorms has been issued for parts of England from Friday, as the Met Office has warned&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByBrett GibbonsRachel Bishop15:11, 24 JUL 2018Updated15:13, 24 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBritain will be battered by thunderstorms and huge hail stones this week, bringing the country's scorching heatwave to a dramatic halt. The Met Office issued a yellow levels alert for Friday covering the East Midlands, east of England, northeast England, northwest England and the Yorkshire and Humber region. Storms could bring torrential downpours with large amounts of rain falling in a short time - But these will be hit-and-miss with many areas missing out completely. A Met Office forecaster said: Whilst many places are likely to remain dry, there is the potential for thunderstorms to develop during Friday afternoon, lasting well into the evening.  Where these occur expect torrential downpours with a much as 30 mm of rainfall in 1 hour and 60 mm in 3 hours. Large hail and strong, gusty winds will be additional hazards. The storm is likely to bring a much welcome break to the searing heatwave this week for many - but for others temperatures could soar to 35C and more on Friday.  A plume of sweltering air dubbed the Mediterranean Melt is set to make Britain hotter than Jamaica by the end of the week as temperatures are set to soar to at least 35C.   The Met Office issued an 'amber alert' urging people to either stay out of the sun or at least find somewhere shady between 11am and 3pm. And Public Health England has issued guidance, warning that vulnerable people could be at risk in the scorching heat. Official figures stated several locations in the UK have had 54 consecutive dry days, starting on May 30, including a few which have had less than 1mm of rain in the entire 54-day period – the longest spell since 1969, when 70 days passed with no significant rainfall.

title: carving modern bicycle found wall
story: NewsCarving of modern bicycle found on wall of 2,000-year-old templeThe founders of Panchavarnaswamy Temple, built during India's ancient Chola period, may have predicted the arrival of the bike by hundreds of years&nbspShareByJoshua TaylorAssistant news editor03:45, 24 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A carving of a modern bicycle has been found on the wall of an ancient 2,000-year-old temple.  The founders of Panchavarnaswamy Temple, which was built during India's ancient Chola period, may have predicted the arrival of the bike by hundreds of years if these images are correct. Praveen Mohan, who found the carving and posted about it on his YouTube channel, said: In a dark corner on one of the walls we can see this amazing carving of a man riding a bicycle. Historians tell us the bicycle was invented in the 1800s, just 200 years ago, but how was this carved in this ancient temple which is about 2,000 years old? The world's first chain-driven bike was developed in around 1885.  Mr Mohan uploaded footage of the discovery online and, sure enough, the carving bears and uncanny resemblance to the kind of bike you'd see today. But there is one possible explanation. Opthalmologist and amateur historian Dr R Kalaikovan also wrote of his bemusement of the sight of the bicycle carving in Panchavarnaswamy Temple.

title: radical feminist oksana shachko found
story: NewsFEMEN founder Oksana Shachko dead at 31: Radical feminist in suspected suicideShachko - credited with starting the topless protests against the sexual exploitation of women which made FEMEN notorious around the world - had been suffering from depression&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByLucy Clarke-Billings12:04, 24 JUL 2018Updated13:08, 24 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA founding member of the radical feminist movement FEMEN has been found dead in her flat in a suspected suicide. Oksana Shachko, 31, who had been suffering from depression for some time, was found in the French capital city of Paris. It was reportedly her third suicide attempt. She was credited with starting the topless protests against the sexual exploitation of women which made FEMEN notorious around the world. Before taking her own life, Ms Shachko left one final message on Instagram, saying: You are fake. It is not clear who was the target of her post.  A post mortem is being carried out on her body to confirm the cause of death. FEMEN member Alisa Vinogradova told CEN: We are shocked and waiting for the autopsy results. Anna Hutsol, who co-founded FEMEN with Ms Shachko and Alexandra Shevchenko, confirmed she had died.  And Ms Shachko's close friend Valeriy Puzik wrote on Facebook: I have known you since you were 16 and I never could imagine that you would take your own life. You were from another planet, a comet that is flying by. I am recalling a handful of memories about you, R.I.P. Ms Shachko, a Ukrainian artist, founded FEMEN with Ms Hutsol and Ms Shevchenko in the Ukrainian capital city of Kiev in April 2008.

title: aussie jesse curran aims to repay faith shown by dundee gaffer neil mccann
story: Dundee youngster Jesse Curran is out to repay Neil McCann’s faith in him as he aims to force his way into the first team at Dens Park.The 22-year-old just recently put pen to paper on a new one-year contract with the Dark Blues and appreciates the chance he’s been given by the club – one he’s desperate to grab with both hands.“Last season was probably the best season I’ve had in terms of playing in Dundee with the new manager coming in and giving me a chance,” he said.“I appreciate that and now just need to kick on this campaign and play as many games as I can and play well.“He’s had faith in me and I need to repay him by working hard and by doing the best I can.“The contract took a while to get sorted, get everything organised, so I was just happy to get it done when I got back.“It was hard keeping in contact being in Australia over the summer.“I’m happy it’s all signed and looking forward to the season.“The gaffer told me he wanted to keep me here and he was happy with me.”Curran made eight first-team appearances last season after just two the previous campaign and is keen to add to that number, starting this Sunday at home to Dunfermline.The young Aussie was mainly used as a right wing-back by gaffer Neil McCann, though, this season he’s preparing for a different role in the team.He said: “I started off in midfield but the gaffer sees me better with the game in front of me where I can run on to the play.“I played at wing-back last season but this campaign it’s all about right-back and trying to learn the position.“My main focus is defending – that’s what I need to work on and just go from there really.”Learning and hard work are key to Curran’s attitude and his down-to-earth nature has him looking up to another player who came up through the youth system at Dens Park.They’ve had completely different routes through their very early careers but Curran is keen to learn from his direct competition at right-back in Cammy Kerr.Kerr burst into the first team in 2016 after working his way up the age groups before making the right full-back position his own for the past couple of seasons.Keeping an eye on how Kerr goes about his work and picking up everything he can is key for Curran – as well as taking in everything he can from a whole range of voices at Dens Park.“I’d say Cammy Kerr is one of the best one-v-one defenders in the league,” Curran added.“I can obviously learn off him every day and get as much as I can just watching him. Even Darren O’Dea has been helping me with my defending and Graham Gartland has helped a lot and every day I’m trying to learn.“If my chance comes I’ll back myself to do the best I can.”Curran came off the bench in the 4-0 win over Stirling last weekend and is hoping to make it appearance No 2 nice and quickly against the Pars on Sunday.He added: “Dunfermline have always been a strong team in the Championship, always competing to get promotion to the Premiership so it will be a good test after they beat Peterhead 3-0 the other night.“There was a great turnout to the Stirling game so, hopefully, we’ll get another good one this weekend.”

title: betfred cup ties remain vital as dundee united work to get going
story: For Dundee United, this season’s Betfred Cup looks all but over but don’t trying telling stand-in skipper Stewart Murdoch the final two group fixtures are meaningless.The 28-year-old knows today&#8217s Tannadice clash with Alloa and next week’s trip to Elgin will be vital games as the Tangerines work to make sure they are a force in the coming Championship campaign.And while the ties so far against Arbroath and Ross County have ended in disappointment in terms of results, he believes they provided proof they’re heading in the right direction.“I think the thing is it’s really early doors and the manager will tell you we are still building, that’s maybe why we haven’t had the results we wanted,” he said.“We are still basically in a pre-season phase, so, for us, Tuesday was a really good competitive game up at County and gave us an opportunity to see exactly where we are right now.“It was another 90 minutes for the lads together and to help get to know each other. When you get the penalty at 0-0 and late on, if you score you probably go on and see out the game.“We didn’t and it was disappointing to lose but at the same time everybody could see the other night that already we can compete and we can take that forward. Now we move on to the next game.”And that need to be ready for next month’s league kick-off against Dunfermline means, for Murdoch and his team-mates, the next two outings are massive.“It will be difficult to qualify from our group now but we will take every game the same way we’ve always done and that’s as big ones.“We probably need to win both games now to have any chance and that’s what we’ll aim to do.“And they are another two big games leading into the start of the season in the Championship. We can get match sharpness and we will have another few boys who’ve had wee injuries back available.“It’s also another opportunity as well for the gaffer to maybe tinker with the team a bit and get boys some game time.”And, despite what the Betfred group table suggests, his belief this rebuilt United side is going to be a force to be reckoned with in the second tier, is growing.“I think everyone is confident we are building a good team and the manager will be wanting a few more players – I’m sure he’d said that.“I think the more good players we add the better we’ll play and the more we play together the better we’ll become.“It gave us confidence going to a place like County and competing the way we did. It was a good performance, it was just the result that was poor.“We are all excited about the season ahead and I think it’s going to be a positive one.”In the absence of newly-appointed club captain Fraser Fyvie, who’s likely to be out for another month or so as he completes his recovery from knee surgery at the turn of the year, the games so far have seen Murdoch wear the captain’s armband.Well aware of United’s history and some of the greats who’ve undertaken the role, he regards even having it on a temporary basis as a big feather in his cap.“I was captain a couple of times towards the end of last season and to be handed it again while Fraser is still out is nice,” he added.“This is a massive club, so to lead Dundee United out in any game is a huge honour for me.”

title: csaba laszlo urging dundee united to speed up
story: Csaba Laszlo wants Dundee United to speed up when their Betfred Cup campaign continues at home to Alloa today.Despite a draw and a penalty shoot-out loss against Arbroath and a narrow defeat at Ross County in the two group ties so far, Csaba has been pleased with the signs coming from his rebuilt Tangerines.The next step forward he wants to see, though, is quicker use of the ball leading to more chances being created.“If I watch the team, Matej Rakovan, Adam Barton, Christoph Rabitsch, Callum Booth and others, they are really good football players,” he said.“They keep the ball well and have some good ideas, but we have to do more in the offence.“You can’t just control the game, you also have to go and finish, bring more danger in front of the opponent’s goal, be quicker.“I told them that for the second half at Ross County, ‘OK we are comfortable with the ball but we have to bring more danger’.”Fraser Aird will be in the squad after he sat out the County trip.

title: disappointed dundee united boss csaba focuses on dunfermline in league opener
story: Dundee United boss Csaba Laszlo was disappointed by his team’s latest Betfred Cup disappointment at the weekend.But he’s reminded fans that it’s all about being ready to win matches when the Championship season kicks off against Dunfermline next week.For the third group stage tie in a row, Saturday saw the Tangerines fail to record a victory as they were held to a draw by Alloa over 90 minutes and then lost the bonus point penalty shootout.It means they have no chance of progressing to the knockout stages and Csaba admitted he was angered by aspects of the performance, particularly during a second half that saw United let the lead slip late on.He isn’t, though, losing sight of the bigger picture.“Again, like the last game, until 80 minutes we are even in front in the game and then make a stupid mistake,” he said.“In the first half I think generally the team played some good football but the second half, according to me, this was not what I want to see. Definitely not.“I think this was to do with the changes we had to make and because we didn’t keep the ball in the front and be more simple.“Nicky Clark was tired and James Keatings has just come back from an injury so he got tired. After that our attacking game was not there.“But I want a team who is ready for Dunfermline, that is ready for the league. We have the two weeks and we go now for the next level.”And Csaba was quick to point out United have not been the only team to have problems in these early season fixtures.“I have watched the results and every big team is struggling. You are not there where you want to be at the moment. This is not an excuse but it is true. If you train every week two times daily you see that legs are tired. Still, with these tired legs you have to win the game one zero, or two zero and finish.”United now head for Elgin City on Saturday knowing they have no chance of qualifying.It will, however, be another vital game as the manager tries to knock his new-look side into shape in their last outing before the league business starts.United’s ‘Meet the fans day’ takes place at Tannadice on Sunday when supporters will get the chance to see the team train.

title: dundee fans and tottenham teammates turn out to pay respects to football legend alan gilzean
story: Fans and former teammates paid tribute to Dundee icon Alan Gilzean on Friday as the legendary striker made his final journey past Dens Park.Supporters young and old braved the rain as the hearse carrying the title-winning forward drove up Sandeman Street just before midday.The ex-Dark Blues and Tottenham Hotspur star died earlier this month aged 79, just weeks after being diagnosed with a brain tumour.Among those to attend his funeral at Dundee Crematorium were several of his ex-Spurs teammates, including Pat Jennings and Alan Mullery.About 80 supporters gathered outside the stadium to pay their respects.Mark Kerr, 64, originally from Lochee, travelled down from Inverness to bid farewell to Mr Gilzean, who he said was one of his heroes.He said: “I was at Dens when Dundee won the league.“I was seven years old and I remember it distinctly.“I watched him playing in Europe and it confirmed I wanted to be a Dundee supporter for life.“I saw Alan at a hall of fame dinner at the Invercarse recently, so I was shocked to hear of his passing.“I’m the chairman of the Highland Dark Blues. I’ve come down from Inverness to pay my respect, and I’ll be raising a drink in his memory tonight.”Born in Coupar Angus, Gilzean is considered one of the finest players to grace Dens Park and netted an unrivalled 169 goals during the halcyon days of the 1950s and 60s.His eye for a goal was a crucial factor in Dundee’s title-winning season in 1961-62, before the club went on to reach the semi-final of the European Cup.Season ticket holder George McLaren, 73, said: “He has been such a big part of Dundee FC. My favourite memories of him are probably the goals against Dundee United.“I was shocked to hear of his passing and wanted to come here today to pay my respects. He will never be forgotten. He proved himself here at Dens and at Spurs.“An absolute legend for both clubs.”Fellow fan Daniel Smith, 33, from Maryfield, added: “There’s been a good turnout of people paying their respects here today at Dens.“He is a Dundee legend. I grew up on stories about Gilzean through the years and the things he accomplished at Dens. He still holds a number of records at Dens Park.”A tribute on the Dundee FC website stated: “Everyone at Dundee Football Club was devastated to learn of the death of Dundee legend Alan Gilzean aged 79 after a short illness.“A true Dundee legend in every sense of the word, we may never see his goal scoring like again and the thoughts of everyone at Dens Park are with Alan’s family and friends at this difficult and sad time.”He made the jump from Tayside to Tottenham in 1964 for a £72,500 fee, lifting two League Cups, the FA Cup and the UEFA Cup.As well as the dark blue of Dundee, Hall of Famer Gilzean earned 22 Scotland caps between 1963 and 1971, bagging 12 goals.

title: dundee people all aboard thehms unicornfor family fun
story: Swashbuckling pirates stormed the HMS Unicorn as people of all ages turned out for the vessel’s summer family fun day.Youngsters dressed up and got the chance to meet unofficial mascot Pirate Bob.Children also had their faces painted and took part in sand art activities.There was even a special curator’s tour of the Music of Maritime Life.Billy Rough, education officer at the Unicorn, said: “It was such a fantastic day.“It was incredibly busy despite it being a glorious sunny day. We were delighted to have live music courtesy of Big Noise Douglas and a motley crew of pirates from Medieval Methil Re-enactment Society entertained families.“Pirate Bob was, of course, on hand to entertain kids with lots of pirate games.“Look out for our next family fun day in October.”The next fun day will take place on October 20.

title: dundee people alyx set for world stage
story: A Monifieth street dancer is to represent Scotland on the world stage.Alyx Gray, 11, is through to the under-12 beginner/novice category at the UDO World Championships at the Hydro in Glasgow.She will also represent the country at the European Championships in the Netherlands next year.Alyx qualified after becoming Scottish champion.The former Seaview Primary pupil, who starts at Monifieth High this year, began dancing aged seven.She is coached by Laura Nisbet, who runs the Addicted 2 Dance studio in Dundee.Mum Jody said: “We are chuffed to bits. She has done us proud and has worked extremely hard.”Established in 2002, UDO is the world’s largest international street dance organisation.

title: dundee people fans dress to impress for 80s rewind
story: It was fun in the sun all the way for the thousands of 1980s fans who enjoyed a bumper weekend of music at Rewind Scotland.As temperatures at Scone Palace soared to the mid 20s the hits of the decade just kept coming.The spectacle kicked off with the Skids on Saturday afternoon followed by a raft of stars including Bob Geldof and his Boomtown Rats, Bonnie Tyler, UB40 and Midge Ure before headline act Status Quo rounded the weekend off in true headbanging style.And as ever the Scottish crowd didn’t let the side down with plenty of neon lycra on show and hundreds of wacky outfits in keeping with the event.

title: dundee people love at first sight and 60 years of marriage based on trust and happiness
story: Sixty years, 21,900 days, 525,000 hours.Last Thursday, these figures signified the length of time since Dundee couple Jim and Isabella Martin were married.Jim and Isabella Martin had been married.They first met at Camperdown Park in 1953 when Jim was 20 and Isabella was just 18.Isabella describes that chance encounter as “love at first sight”.“I was on a walk round Camperdown Park and Jim was there playing football with his friends,” she said.“The ball came rolling over and landed at my feet. When I saw Jim coming over, my heart was booming.“From then on our love flourished.”Five years later, after Jim proposed in Dublin, the happy couple were married at the High Kirk in Dundee on July 19 1958.In preparation for the big day, Jim lost a stone in weight, which he claims was due to all the worry.Isabella looked stunning in a white lace ballerina-style dress which she says still has “tomato stains down the front”.Jim and Isabella went on to have two sons and a daughter, and 10 grandchildren have followed.Isabella said: “Family has always been first and foremost in our life and to this day we still have a close bond with our family.“We enjoy cruises and have travelled the world, with our children occasionally joining us.”Sixty years is a long time but Jim and Isabella say the secret behind how long they have stayed together so long is very easy.“Our marriage has been based on love, trust and happiness,” said Isabella.“The problem with couples these days is that they just don’t trust each other.“For us it was love at first sight and to this day we still care so much about each other.”The Martins will be celebrating their anniversary with friends and family at Invercarse Hotel next week.

title: dundee people manjeet retires after 22 years
story: After 22 years of service, Manjeet Grill, co-ordinator at The Corner Dundee, a health and information service, is retiring.Starting out as a sessional worker encouraging young people from minority ethnic backgrounds to access citywide health services, she became an assistant project leader and then co-ordinator in 2011.Manjeet said: “Over the years I have been part of many changes at The Corner.“One of its successes is to be able to adapt, evolve and be responsive to young people’s needs. The Corner always has a multi-professional team which brings mixed skills to enable us to respond to the complexity of the needs of young people.”

title: dundee people photo exhibitionbrings dundee life into focus
story: A photography exhibition has been unveiled showcasing Dundee life in the modern era.Red Sky Photography’s survey of Dundee is the result of a full year of work by a dozen local shutterbugs, who snapped 5,500 frames of city living throughout 2017.The collective has captured a snapshot of the city frozen in time – celebrating its people, its new-found cultural relevance and much of its architecture, old and new.The full selection of images now forms a permanent collection in Dundee Libraries’ Local History Department, joining previous surveys carried out in 1991 and 1916.About 40 of those were hand-picked by Red Sky to create an exhibition that will be on show in Central Library until next week and later tour libraries around the city.Dundee-born Ian Crighton, one of the photographers involved in the project, said the group was given free rein in choosing what they captured.“It was a fairly open process as we set about the survey. We just captured events and places that we thought were significant,” he said.“There are photos of people, of events, the arts, dance activities, things such as the New Year’s Day Dook and a lot of buildings that we thought either were significant or would become significant.“I was given access to Dens Park, for example, because I imagine in 10 years or so it might no longer exist as we know it.“I’m quite surprised at what we’ve been able to achieve.”The Tele was given access to some of the archive and the differences in city life now and then are stark.The 1916 survey features street scenes in the city centre and atop the Hilltown – and couldn’t be any more different from the snaps from 1991.Many of the later images show the city at its post-industrial peak, complete with questionable fashion choices and a City Square yet to be pedestrianised.Red Sky’s modern day survey is packed with sights that are likely to be familiar now – the new railway station entrance under construction, rusted-in tram rails on the Murraygate and dance performances in front of Caird Hall.Rather topically, there are also photos of William Halley’s mill – now reduced to rubble.Alistair Wilson, of Dundee Libraries, said the relevance of these photographic surveys becomes very clear after just a few years, giving people a fresh perspective on a city that might have changed without them really noticing.“The 1991 survey was carried out by Dundee Photographic Society. It and the other surveys act like a social record of how the city was at that time,” he said.“Looking back at 1991, which doesn’t feel that long ago, you can see so many things have changed – the way people dress, the jobs they have, even the cars on the streets.“Once the exhibition finishes the plan is that it will move about so everyone can see it.”

title: dundee people pop up shop peps up charity
story: A pop-up ladies boutique in Broughty Ferry has raised several thousand pounds for charity.The shop in Gray Street has raised £7,600 for the Cystic Fibrosis Trust (CFT) in just two weeks.Cystic fibrosis is a genetic condition that affects the lungs and other organs.Morag Beckett, who set up the shop, said: “It’s been brilliant. We were lucky because the first week was Broughty Ferry gala week and the weather was glorious.“I want to thank people for their donations, for volunteering and those who came in and bought things.”Picture shows, from left, Hilary Carver, Laura Ross, piper Greg Beckett, Morag, CFT fundraising manager in Scotland Nicola Holland and Fiona Beckett.

title: dundee united set to announce signing eleventh signing of the summer
story: Dundee United are set to unveil former Falkirk defender Paul Watson.The 27-year-old will be Csaba Laszlo&#8217s eleventh signing of the summer.Watson made 49 appearances for the Bairns in a three-year spell before being released by Paul Hartley at the end of last season.The centre back made 24 appearances last season &#8211 including Falkirk&#8217s 6-1 mauling of United in January.More soon&#8230

title: former dundee and dundee united star simon murray joins south african club
story: Hibernian have confirmed the departure of Simon Murray, who has joined South African outfit Bidvest Wits.The striker, 26, moved to Easter Road from Dundee United last summer and had a year remaining on his contract.Murray made 29 Hibs appearances, scoring 14 goals, including a winning strike against Edinburgh rivals Hearts.He spent the latter half of last term on loan at Dundee, netting three goals in 14 outings.Bidvest Wits won the South African Premier Division in 2017, but finished last term 13th in the 16-team league.After the deal was confirmed, Murray tweeted: “Thanks for allowing me to play for such a great club and meet some of the best people.“Won’t forget my goal in the derby in a hurry! But now time for another challenge and I am delighted to join Bidvest Wits.”

title: get ready dundee to experience longest lunar eclipse of the century
story: Dundonians will be well placed later this week to have a grandstand view of the longest lunar eclipse, or blood moon, of the century.City group Dundee Culture has prepared a definitive guide of the best spots to head for in the city to get the optimum view of the natural phenomenon.Andrew Batchelor, founder of Dundee Culture, said: “The longest lunar eclipse this century takes place on Friday.“We have put together a guide to let people know where to find the best places to watch it.“The total lunar eclipse will last three hours in total and be visible from Dundee at moonrise.”Andrew explained that the eclipse in the city will start at 9.38pm.He said: “As the eclipse continues, it will be at peak position at 9.50pm and end at 10.13pm making it 35 minutes long. The full eclipse will then end at 00.28am on Saturday.“Dundee Law will probably be the best place to watch the lunar eclipse.At moonrise, you will be able to see the start from the east, looking towards Broughty Ferry.“As the Dundee Law is the highest point in the city, you are bound to get great views of the total lunar eclipse.“Balgay Hill is another great place to watch the eclipse from.“I spoke with Mills Observatory and unfortunately they will not be opening for the lunar eclipse.“However, Balgay Hill will still be a great place to view it. You just need to look east and you should see it rise above Broughty Ferry.“The Tay Road Bridge or somewhere across the Tay would be another ideal spot although lower than the Law and Balgay Hill.“Observers should still have a great view as it continues to rise above the horizon.” A lunar eclipse occurs when the moon passes directly behind the Earth and into its shadow.This can occur only when the sun, Earth and the moon are aligned exactly with the planet in between.It can occur only on the night of a full moon.The type and length of an eclipse depends on the moon’s proximity to either node of its orbit.During a total lunar eclipse, Earth completely blocks direct sunlight from reaching the moon.The only light reflected from the lunar surface has been refracted by Earth’s atmosphere.This light appears reddish for the same reason that a sunset or sunrise does.Due to this reddish colour, a totally eclipsed moon is sometimes called a blood moon.

title: give alan gilzean a proper dens park send off says dundee ace cammy kerr
story: Dundee favourite Cammy Kerr has called on the club’s supporters to give Alan Gilzean the send off the Dens legend deserves this weekend.The Dark Blues take on Dunfermline this Sunday in the first home game since Gilzean passed away at the age of 79.The club legend’s funeral takes place tomorrow and Sunday’s clash promises to be one full of emotion for everyone associated with Dundee.A special matchday programme will be available while there will be a minute’s silence and black armbands worn by the players but Kerr expects a bumper home crowd to give Gilzean a roaring send-off.The 22-year-old said: “It’s a terrible thing to happen.“Sadly, I never got to see him play or have the privilege of meeting him but what a figure to have played at this football club.“To know you are at the same football club as some of the greatest footballers have played at is fantastic.“I’d like to send my regards and best wishes to his family at this time, obviously a tough time.“In terms of the game, I think it will be emotional and, hopefully, the crowd turn out for a very special player for this football club.“I’ve read a few of things in the papers about the player he was and I actually remember watching the thing on TV at White Hart Lane when they closed the old stadium.“I knew he was a good player but I didn’t know how big he was for Tottenham.“When they said ‘The Original King of White Hart Lane, Alan Gilzean’ it just shows the regard he was held in down there.“Naming a lounge after him doesn’t do him justice because he was, obviously, a great talent.”Being a fan himself, Kerr knows the kind of supporters Dundee have and the loyalty they show their team – something he experienced in a very noisy welcome and send-off at last week’s friendly against Farense in Portugal.“We could hear them when we got off the bus in Albufeira but you can’t see how many there were,” Kerr added.“At the end I got a few photos and things and they were singing away.“The best bit was when we were leaving and they were all banging on the bus – it was great!“You see European games and all the fans waiting on the buses so it felt like that, it felt great.“For the fans to go across there just shows the loyalty that they’ll go across to Portugal for a friendly. That’s fantastic to see.“I gave away a pair of my boots and I think someone had them on running about the streets about 10 minutes later!”Allan Johnston’s Pars side will be looking to spoil Dundee’s return to the newly-named Kilmac Stadium at Dens Park by putting themselves into pole position in Betfred Cup Group D.And Kerr knows the Dark Blues will have to be right on their game to see off a Dunfermline side that swept past Peterhead in midweek.He added: “The game is on the TV as well which is good and the pitch is coming on really well, too. The groundsmen do a great job to give us a good pitch.“It’s always good to come out and have a game on the TV, it’s exciting, but Dunfermline are a side that will definitely try to push this year.“They’ve made some really important signings throughout their side and they’ll be a really tough test, so we’ll have to be firing on all cylinders.”

title: go ahead given for 30 affordable new dwellings in dundee
story: A housing association has won permission to raze an industrial complex and replace it with 30 new-build homes.Caledonia Housing Association said it was “pleased” to have obtained planning consent to build on the former Charles Gray Builders site in Coldside.Its application to demolish buildings nestled on the edges of Coldside Road and Hospital Street was submitted in December by local architecture firm KDM Architects.In all, 30 “affordable” homes will be built, comprised of a mix of 18 houses and 12 flats across two three-storey blocks.A new cul-de-sac will be created as part of the works.Funding for the purchase of the land is being provided by Dundee City Council, as well as guidance to Caledonia on the types of homes that are in demand.Once the purchase has been finalised, the firm hopes to begin work on the site before the end of the year, with the project due to be completed in about 12 months.A spokeswoman for Caledonia Housing Assoication said: “We are pleased to have gained planning approval for the 30 new affordable homes for rent on Coldside Road in Dundee, including some support accommodation for the city council.“We hope to finalise project details in the coming months with a view to starting work on site before the end of the year.“The project is expected to be completed by early 2020.”Four letters of objection to the plans were received by the city council.However, planning officers at the local authority said all concerns shared by locals had been addressed.While the proposal does not tie in with the council’s aspirations for the area – as described in the local authority’s local development plan – officers saw fit to wave the application through to meet housing demand.However, 18 conditions have been attached to the approval which Caledonia must meet, including having all roadway plans approved by the city council before construction and provision being made for electric car charging points.The council said in a follow-on report: “There are material considerations in addressing a specific local housing need that justify approval of planning permission.”

title: huge emergency response as woman gets trapped under lorry on local road for 40 minutes
story: A 72-year-old woman was seriously injured when she was trapped under a heavy goods vehicle for 40 minutes in the centre of St Andrews.Witnesses said she fell from the pavement into the path of the oncoming HGV, which was travelling down Bell Street.The pensioner was taken to Ninewells Hospital in Dundee following a large-scale response from the emergency services.One witness, who works in a Bell Street shop, said: “She seemed to lose her balance and when she fell her arm was on the road as the truck came.“She was under the truck for maybe 40 minutes. She was in shock and shaking.“She screamed when it happened but after that was quiet. She was brave.”The witness said that she, along with other shop workers, used advertising boards for their businesses to create a barrier around the injured woman.A tarpaulin tent was erected near the HGV once the emergency services arrived.

title: i thought she was on the same level as little mix tickets to see rita ora in dundee on sale for just 19
story: Dundonians have voiced their surprise after a firm was advertising tickets to see Rita Ora in Dundee for just £19.The singer will perform at Slessor Gardens in front of thousands of fans on Saturday, July 28.Fans were originally asked to pay £39.50 for general admission or £55 to gain access to the golden circle.However, an itison Dundee offer advertises general admission tickets to the gig for £19.The bargain briefs went on sale through the “deal service” at 7am this morning, bragging of a 57% saving.Folk in Dundee had sympathy with fans who forked out the full price.Support worker Charlie McDonash, 61, told the Tele: “It’s unfair that people have bought them at that price and they’ve went on sale for £19. They’re just ripping people off.”Student nurse Nicole Halliday, 21, said: “I know people who are going that got priority tickets and had to get babysitters to go and now the tickets are getting slashed so it really could have benefited them if the tickets were cheaper at the time.&#8220I’m really surprised it’s not busier and they’ve had to slash prices. I don’t remember them doing that for Little Mix and I thought Rita Ora was on the same level as them.”An itison spokeswoman said: “We always aim to give our members access to the best quality experiences and today we’ve given several thousand people the chance to see the amazing Rita Ora live at Slessor Gardens.“In the world we live in, prices fluctuate across all industries whether that’s a meal out or a break away, going to an event or booking travel  – it’s part of today’s market place.“We want to see more people having a great time and we hope everyone going to the concert will have a brilliant night.”Itison also confirmed that multiple ticket purchases are being permitted.A statement from Lizz Hobbs Group Live, the promoter behind the Slessor Gardens gig, read: “itison are a new ticketing partner which we intend to offer an allocation of tickets to at the launch of a new event to benefit all ticket buyers for concerts at Dundee Slessor Gardens.“We are delighted that the allocation of tickets have been so well received and look forward to seeing everyone at Dundee Slessor Gardens on Saturday evening for what is sure to be another wonderful concert.”

title: kharl madianga set to make first dundee start
story: With midfielder Glen Kamara expected to be missing for Dundee this weekend, Kharl Madianga is expected to get his first chance from the start against Dunfermline.The Dark Blues host the Pars in Betfred Cup Group D on Sunday with Finnish international Kamara a big doubt after a training-ground clash left him with a protective boot on his foot.The club are hoping the damage is minimal and the use of the boot is purely a precaution.However, it’s unlikely he’ll be risked for the weekend game with Allan Johnston’s side.That means French midfielder Madianga is in line for a first competitive start since signing for the club over the summer.The former French U/17 international joined the club from Bulgarian side Lokomotiv GO – the same side Sofien Moussa was signed from.He made his competitive debut for the Dark Blues last weekend in the 4-0 victory at Stirling Albion, coming off the bench for fellow-new boy Elton Ngwatala.And manager Neil McCann said after that game Madianga was one Dundee fans should look forward to seeing in action.“Kharl came on and showed glimpses as well, he’s a fantastic player so in the midfield I think we have some real exciting talent in there,” the Dens gaffer said.Also missing at the moment for Dundee is winger Roarie Deacon.He’s continuing his recovery from ankle surgery and is expected to be out for a while yet.Club skipper Darren O’Dea missed the win at Stirling last week, and two friendlies in Portugal the previous week, with a groin problem.

title: tributes to dundee legend jim who dedicated 64 years to junior football
story: Tributes have been paid to Lochee Harp legend Jim Kelly who has died age 85.Jim served as chairman of the Beechwood Park Club for more than 40 years and was a popular figure among the junior football world.Jim dedicated 64 years of his life to junior football and developing Lochee Harp’s young talent.His son, Mike, who followed his lead and made more than 1,000 appearances for the club, said: “He had a phenomenal impact and was pretty much Mr Lochee Harp.“My dad took over the club when it was virtually on the verge of closing. He gave a lot of guys their first shot in the game and signed me too.“The Kellys are synonymous with Lochee Harp. Everyone knew him as a gentleman. Not everyone agreed with him but he was respected.”The club tweeted: “He leaves a massive hole in the hearts of his family and everyone connected to the club. Our thoughts go out to them and his wife Anne.”Before working on the committee and coaching team at Lochee Harp, he played as a junior footballer for local clubs including St Josephs, Alyth United, Stobswell, Downfield and also Harp.Throughout his time as a player, he competed in the old Dundee Junior League in the Forfarshire, Courier, Loftus and Keddie Cups.Shortly after being given a long-service award from the Scottish Junior FA in 2014, he told the Tele: “From there, it just seemed a natural progression to secretary and then eventually chairman. In actual fact, I don’t mind being tagged with being just a general ‘dogsbody.’”He received a Lifetime Achievement Award at the Dundee City Council Sports Awards in 2016 for his service to Harp.Jim was treasurer of the Dundee Junior League and Tayside Junior League. Later, he served as finance and general committee member of the Scottish Junior FA.A passionate committee man with Lochee Harp, he initially resisted any attempt to regionalise the leagues: “Most local clubs were against it and myself, Downfield’s Alex Connelly, Charlie Fairfield of St Joseph, Broughty Athletic’s Eddie Whitton and others threatened to pull away and form our own league.“We could have done that as there were 12 teams in Dundee at the time. The SFA president came through to try to talk us round. We had a meeting with North End Park and were initially threatened with some form of blacklisting if we didn’t comply with the SJFA’s plans.”His son admitted his dad was modest about his achievements, saying: “He wanted Harp to be the best. He will be missed by us and the club.”

title: Claims that electricity substation is affecting house values
story: Residents in a remote Inverness-shire glen are challenging a power giant over a massive electricity substation that is expanding towards their homes.The 12 or so residents at Auchterawe near Fort Augustus fear their idyllic homes&rsquo value has been slashed and the peaceful area blighted as the Scottish and Southern Electricity (SSE) substation expands to become one of the biggest around."From a tiny substation it is going to become an industrial site," said Steve Lanning who is leading the fight for compensation from SSE."For years SSE has been developing the small substation into what promises to become a huge facility. It has completely blighted the community and many homes are now unsaleable."He said the proposed expansion would bring the substation boundary within 30 yards of the nearest property, and 75 yards of his home.He added: "SSE refuses to acknowledge any fault or offer compensation of any kind."There appears to be no clearly established legal obligation for SSE to compensate, but there is a moral one, considering the substantial financial loss suffered by the residents and the spoiling of a peaceful rural atmosphere."He added that the planning authority, Highland Council, has expressed little interest in helping them.Mr Lanning said that in February he was forced to take his house off the market after a year because he could not sell it at &pound40,000 below the market value.The substation began growing to accommodate the Beauly to Denny power line and the new renewable energy sources in the surrounding hills.Pensioner Mr Lanning, who has lived in the glen for 11 years, said: "The substation has been enlarged about four times."There are liaison meetings but they are simply PR exercises."This is not just about me. The other residents are my friends and we are all in the same boat."A spokeswoman from SSE said: "Our proposal has been developed in close consultation with the local community and other stakeholders based on a range of economic, environmental and technical considerations.&nbsp"As a responsible developer, we have listened carefully to the feedback during consultation, and to minimise the visual impact of the extension, we are proposing a gas-insulated switchgear solution, which significantly reduces the footprint of the site."We have also purchased additional land to allow for enhanced screening and bunding to further mitigate the visual impact."We remain committed to working constructively with the local community."She added that there have been two public consultations, and SSE also facilitate a dedicated community&nbspliaison group in the area where senior management and project teams are on hand to engage directly with residents to address any concerns raised.A detailed planning application has been lodged and a council planning decision is expected in September.A Highland Council spokeswoman said: "Our decision will take into account all relevant matters including the potential impact of the development on third parties."It is not the responsibility however of local government to provide compensation to third parties who may consider they have been impacted upon by developments as a result of a planning decision."Tuesday 24 Jul 2018 4:35 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Dancer is all smiles after major Canada win
story: &nbspA HIGHLAND dancing champion has scooped one of her highest accolades yet after triumphing in an international dance competition.Lily Kelman (11) is a member of the Fraser School of Highland Dance and travelled to the ScotDance Canada Championships Series in Calgary, Alberta recently, where she took on fellow dancers from all over the world.Clearly not fazed by the competition she was ultimately named Open Canadian Champion for her age group.The competition was her fifth championship event and she won all three categories she entered &ndash Highland competition, Premiership National Championship and Open Highland Championship.This latest victory followed on from a runner-up spot at the SDTA Central Scotland Championshps earlier this year, an impressive placing that was itself followed by her first Open Championship title secured at the UK Alliance Championships in Edinburgh, in which she saw off 33 other top competitors.Her younger sister Grace (9) also competed in the Canadian event, in the intermediate section, and came home with five medals.Provost Helen Carmichael had met both girls before they set off across the Atlantic and was delighted to welcome them back to Inverness Town House this week."Lily is an excellent example of what our young people can achieve with commitment and sheer endeavour," she said."While I congratulate Lily on her personal achievements I also commend the role that she is playing through her participation in international Highland dance competitions as a young ambassador for Inverness and the Highlands."She added: "Before Lily and Grace left for Canada, I was delighted to donate Inverness Town House pin badges to both girls so that they could take part in the pin exchange which took place at the start of the championship series."The girls acted as ambassadors for Inverness, exchanging pins between dancers of many different nationalities."Lily' mother Yvonne said: "A staggering 980 dancers were entered into the ScotDance competition as a whole and from that 10 girls in total came from Inverness &ndash&nbsp seven from the Claire Bryce School of Highland Dance and three from the Fraser School of Dance, both Inverness."All girls did amazingly well and came home with a haul of medals and trophies."Tuesday 24 Jul 2018 4:35 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Inverness pub submits plans for new street cafe by the castle
story: &nbspA POPULAR pub close to Inverness Castle has applied for permission to build a new street caf&eacute nearby.The owners of the Castle Tavern want to take over a small plot of landscaped land just a stone' throw from its premises in View Place.Owner Jane Wilson said efforts had been made to trace the owners of the land, to enquire about buying or leasing it, but ownership "cannot be determined".The area is currently maintained by Highland Council but she said staff at the pub also worked to keep it tidy and litter-free.In a statement to support the application, she says: "This piece of land forms part of the adopted road and, as such, we have lodged an application for permission to occupy the road with a street caf&eacute."Given its proximity to an area of the town that has so much tourist interest, we feel we could make use of the land and that this would benefit visitors to the town as well as our business."The Castle Tavern is located across from the end and beginning of the Great Glen Way and, as such, we have a large number of visitors - walkers and cyclists."The beer garden that we have is small and we are limited in how many cycles we can accommodate. The only other place for them is on the footpath. This can cause restricted use of the path for pedestrians and customers."Our plans for the area are to tidy it up and improve the landscaping, insert some tables and benches and a secure area for housing bicycles."The plot, she added, would be serviced by the Castle Tavern' CCTV and be maintained to a high standard.There are also possible longer-term plans to install a charging point for electric bikes."The use of this land would be mainly seasonal as we do not intend to put any building on it and it would be used primarily for visitors who currently cycle or walk the Great Glen Way," she said.Inverness Central councillor Bet McAllister said she thought it was a "wonderful" idea for tourists and residents alike."It will be perfect for when the weather is nice and people want to sit outside for their meals," she said."The Castle Tavern is always very busy, especially their outside area."Cllr McAllister wants to encourage more restaurants and bars to utilise outdoor areas as long as they are able to ensure that people with disabilities are not impacted."In Inverness our streets can be quite narrow, so it has to be done properly," she said.Glad to hear that the move by the Castle Tavern could benefit cyclists, she added: "The more bikes on the roads in Inverness the better the quality of air for everyone."Tuesday 24 Jul 2018 4:35 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: New 40k artwork unveiled for Ness Islands
story: &nbspA &pound40,000 artwork which would enable children to paddle in and enjoy the water at the Ness Islands is the latest offering from the Inverness River Connections project.&nbspIf approved by councillors, it will consist of patterned sculptural stepping stones made of granite, sitting in a stainless steel channel or lade.Water from the river will feed into this channel where some of the stones will be fitted with moveable sluice gates to allow children to control the flow of water themselves.The plan is for it to be located in the middle of the Ness Islands at a spot already popular with families.The proposal is just one element of the River Ness Public Art Project, worth a total of &pound727,000.Inverness Provost Helen Carmichael was yesterday hopeful that the concept would find favour with councillors on Highland Council' south planning committee, especially since local schoolchildren had been consulted on what they would like to see there, and Inverness College UHI design students had input on the concept.She said: "Children were very involved along with students at the university. Children love jumping from stone to stone and guddling about in water."It has all been looked at from the safety point of view, but let' face it, if you take children to the beach they jump from stone to stone. I think it is a good project and if necessary I will be the first to dip my toe in the water there."Inverness city manager David Haas said: "This has had youth engagement all along and I think it is something that is going to sit well in the environment of a place that will become even more popular as people engage with the river."Masterminding the project is Bespoke Atelier, a Glasgow-based design studio.Its design statement, which will be discussed at a planning meeting later this summer, explains the lades and weirs already around the River Ness were used as inspiration. The stones would be patterned, partly to minimise slips and also to reflect foliage patterns from trees growing on the islands.A report from Inverness City Artworks Group states: "While it was preferable to use natural stone, the cost might prove prohibitive and alternative materials might need to be considered."It was also minuted that if concerns were raised regarding the cost of this feature, the high cost of "providing basic play equipment should be highlighted."The group was given assurances that the design would, when completed, look like part of the landscape, and members were told that Bespoke Atelier was confident that all aspects of the design could be met within the available budget.Path improvements in the vicinity are included in the application.Company director Yvonne Elliot-Kellighan said the stepping stone forms envisaged were inspired by the shape of the Ness Islands, and the stones themselves could be engraved with botanical patterns "creating a ow and connection between stepping stones".The children' feature is not far from MY Ness, a &pound300,000 centrepiece which was unveiled as a concept in May and has still to receive planning permission.The River Ness Public Art Project is funded by Creative Scotland (&pound305,000), Inverness Common Good Fund (&pound250,000), HIE (&pound66,000) and Highland Council (&pound106,000).At a time of heightened concern about public spending, Highland Council has stressed that the vast majority of the money for the projects comes from third parties and cannot be used for other purposes, and the council' &pound106k is from capital investment and not revenue spend.Tuesday 24 Jul 2018 4:35 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: New cinema proposed for the Black Isle
story: &nbspA THRIVING film society on the Black Isle looks set to take its next big step after plans were submitted for a permanent cinema to cater for growing demand.The brand new cinema, which would be located on the seafront in Cromarty, will cater to Cromarty and Resolis Film Society events and serve as a base for the town' increasingly popular annual film festival.Cromarty Estate, which owns the land, has lodged the application in partnership the film society, which would act as its tenant.The plans feature two key elements. The first is the cinema, which would be built on land close to the ferry slipway and next to an existing boat storage shed.The cinema would seat roughly 30 people and host weekly screenings throughout the year, rising to twice a week in the summer. It would also be used to help house Cromarty' growing film festival, which attracts fans and famous faces from across the country late every autumn.Cromarty Estate also plans to build an office hub alongside the cinema in a bid to cater for growing business demand in the town.In a supporting statement submitted by the estate alongside its application, its agents said: "A dedicated cinema space will allow screening all year which currently is not possible using existing buildings with poor black out facilities."The cinema may also be available for other users to hire for screenings, presentations and lectures."They added that the cinema would also "ideally" feature an outdoor area "for summer screenings and festival events".Making the case for new office space in the town, the estate said: "Cromarty has a thriving entrepreneurial community but this is not matched by suitable office accommodation with the result that many find themselves having to move their business bases from Cromarty to Dingwall, Tore or Inverness when they outgrow their own homes, with the resulting loss of employment opportunities in the town."Addressing this need... will make Cromarty a more balanced and sustainable community."In a statement supporting the application, the film society said that a survey of Cromarty residents found that 82 per cent backed a cinema in the town and the same number would go to more screenings if the venue was better than what is currently on offer.Justifying the decision to proceed with an all-new site for the cinema, the estate' agents said the site' position close to adequate parking and its location away from homes were both positives, as was the existing vehicle access from the harbour.The buildings would feature dark metal cladding to the walls of the cinema, with timber cladding on the office hub.If the plans are approved construction could start as early as spring next year.Tuesday 24 Jul 2018 4:35 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Pamiloo to make its first visit to Black Isle Show
story: &nbspCAMPAIGNERS have welcomed news that accessible toilets will be installed at this year' Black Isle Show &ndash allowing people with complex needs to enjoy the event.Fiona MacLeod-Chiarini, whose brother Ewan MacLeod is severely disabled, contacted the show' organisers to ask about the availability of a Pamiloo (right), a mobile facility for those with profound impairments.Rod Mackenzie, the Black Isle Show' company secretary, immediately got in touch with the charity Promoting a More Inclusive Scotland (Pamis), which owns the Pamiloo, in order to make the event accessible for the family.Mrs MacLeod-Chiarini hailed the move, and believes facilities such as the Pamiloo can be life-changing.She said: "We are absolutely delighted that the Black Isle Show have taken our concerns on board and have booked the Pamiloo. They were so helpful."It can be very hard for disabled people to go to these events because quite often, normal disabled toilets are just not adequate."We usually manage to get by but sometimes the process is not very dignified."You do get used to getting by with what is there but when you discover something like this, the difference it makes is amazing."It may sound over-dramatic to say it' life-changing but it genuinely is."It makes life so much easier and more dignified for people like Ewan."Mr Mackenzie said: "The Black Isle Farmers&rsquo Society are delighted to have secured this excellent facility and further enhancing accessibility to all."A spokeswoman for Pamis said: "Pamis are delighted that the Black Isle Show has responded to the need of a local family and booked the Pamiloo."Without these facilities, which include space for a wheelchair and two carers, a hoist and tracking system and an adult changing bench, thousands of families across the country cannot go out or are faced with changing loved ones on the floor of a public toilet."Having access to a Changing Places toilet empowers families to go out and enjoy day trips like everyone else."Mrs MacLeod-Chiarini would now like to see the Pamiloo at more public events, to make them accessible to all.She added: "We would like to see more events make use of the Pamiloo, or even install their own facilities, especially in the Highlands where there is such a distance to travel."A lot of people have not got the option of going out because it' so difficult for them."Letting people know about the Pamiloo is important and hopefully there will be more people and organisations taking the points on board."The more people who know about it the better."Tuesday 24 Jul 2018 4:35 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Play set to bring story of the Caledonian Canal to life
story: Fort Augustus will become Scottish Canals&rsquo latest outdoor pop-up theatre venue this summer.Waters of Time, the new bespoke Canal Theatre play produced by the Walking Theatre Company, is set against the making of the Caledonian Canal and uses the Fort Augustus lock staircase as its stage.The cast will take visitors on a journey through time, exploring the canal' history.The programme celebrates the opening of Scottish Canals&rsquo new Caledonian Canal Centre in Fort Augustus, a visitor and destination hub which opened in May.The centre offers new, all year round, facilities for visitors and locals, including information, a gift shop promoting locally sourced goods and a caf&eacute serving homemade produce.Visitor interpretation is incorporated throughout the centre, unlocking the wealth of local heritage and internationally renowned local features of the Caledonian Canal, Great Glen and Loch Ness. Seven holiday rooms are also available to let for guests who want to make Fort Augustus their base, bookable through Airbnb.The creation of the centre was supported by VisitScotland and the Heritage Lottery Fund Scotland, and was awarded &pound237,500 of Coastal Communities Funding.This contributed to the &pound1.2 million redevelopment of existing vacant premises in Fort Augustus, bringing the redundant building back into a productive and sustainable use.Mark Smith, head of destinations and tourism at Scottish Canals, said: "The new Caledonian Canal Centre is an exciting addition to the canal side at Fort Augustus. During the development of this project we have been working closely with the local community to develop the stories of the canal and bring our rich heritage to life, and we look forward to continuing this."We&rsquore delighted to welcome Canal Theatre to Fort Augustus to mark the opening of the new centre, and we&rsquore sure that visitors and locals alike will enjoy meandering through the years with the play' characters."Performances start on Wednesday and tickets cost &pound7 with it being free for under-5s.For more, visit www.scottishcanals/destinations/fort-augustus/Tuesday 24 Jul 2018 4:35 PM&nbsp&nbsp
